caution.para: To prevent engine damage, (if replacing glow plug sleeves in chassis), place a small dab of grease into the bottom of the glow plug sleeve prior to cutting threads. The grease will prevent small metal chips from entering the combustion chamber.

note.para: Glow plug sleeve removal is not required unless the sleeve is leaking. See Cleaning, Inspection and Tests in this section to determine if sleeve replacement is required.

figure.caption: Lubricating Glow Plug Sleeve Remover (thread tap)

step1.para: Lubricate Glow Plug Sleeve Remover (thread tap). See Special Service Tools.

note.para: The glow plug sleeve is made of stainless steel. Lubrication of the Glow Plug Sleeve Remover (thread tap) is required, otherwise excessive force will be necessary to get the threads started.

figure.caption: Installing the Glow Plug Sleeve Remover (thread tap)

step1.para: Install Glow Plug Sleeve Remover (thread tap) to cut threads in the glow plug sleeve. Cut threads at least ½ inch deep to accommodate Glow Plug Sleeve Remover (bolt and sleeve adapter). See Special Service Tools.

figure.caption: Installing the Glow Plug Sleeve Remover

step1.para: Thread Glow Plug Sleeve Remover (bolt and sleeve adapter) into glow plug sleeve. See Special Service Tools.

figure.caption: Removing sleeve with Glow Plug Sleeve Remover

step1.para: Using a wrench tighten the bolt in the remover until the glow plug sleeve adapter is extracted.
Remove glow plug sleeve and discard.
Clean glow plug bore with Glow Plug Sleeve Brush. See Special Service Tools.
